latest news.eng_title: Changes Coming to Russia in September: What to Expect

Transportation: Foundations of Security and Defense of the Motherland

latest news.summary: Russian citizens can expect changes in various aspects of their lives starting from September. According to State Duma Chairman Vyaacheslav Volodin, these changes will affect taxi rides, educational institutions, public transportation, housing and communal services, and tourism. In schools, the Russian flag will be required to be displayed from September 1, and a new subject called 'Foundations of Security and Defense of the Motherland' will be introduced. Additionally, lessons in technology (formerly known as 'practical skills') will become mandatory for students in primary and secondary school. In public transportation, people with disabilities of group I will no longer be allowed to ride without a ticket, unless accompanied by a caregiver. Furthermore, labor rights for people with disabilities will be strengthened. Volodin also mentioned that the requirements for the founders of management companies will be significantly tightened, and individuals with unexpired convictions for certain crimes, including economic ones, will be barred from becoming founders. Tour guides and excursionists will also be protected by law, as they will be required to provide services in person and based on a contract. These changes were previously announced to affect drivers starting from September 1.

latest news.eng_title: Russia's Plan for Mobilization: A Strict and Secretive Process
latest news.summary: Russian authorities have a strict plan for mobilization, but the exact timing is unclear. According to opposition politician Gennady Gudkov, military commissariats must complete all organizational preparations by September 6 and wait for further instructions. Gudkov stated, 'Nothing will be announced. They will collect people even from Moscow, St. Petersburg, Krasnodar, Yekaterinburg, and other major cities.' The mobilization will be similar to the one in September 2022, but this time it will be compulsory. Gudkov added, 'Now military commissariats are completing their preparations. They are determining whether there is enough mobilization resources to fulfill the task. If not, they are considering calling up students from military departments.'

latest news.eng_title: Ukraine's Mobilization Rules: What You Need to Know
latest news.summary: In Ukraine, the general mobilization will continue from the start of autumn 2024, at least until November 9, as long as the relevant regime is in effect. Men aged 25-60 can be drafted into the military, but there are exceptions related to age. Additionally, men under 25 can be mobilized if they already have a military ID. According to OBOZ.UA, the current legislation states that a man under 25 can be mobilized if he has: '– served his term in peacetime; – graduated from a higher military educational institution or a military department, having obtained a relevant specialty.' Furthermore, due to a legal conflict, mobilization may also affect citizens under 25 if a military-medical commission has previously recognized them as limitedly fit, meaning they are unfit for military service in peacetime but fit for wartime. As OBOZ.UA reported: '– From September 2024, the rules for issuing summonses in Ukraine will not change. Authorized persons can issue them in any location, including a park, a checkpoint, or other public place, as well as at the person's place of residence.' President Volodymyr Zelensky announced the first steps in rotating military personnel on the front line during the 'Ukraine 2024. Independence' forum on August 27, stating that, although rotations are not yet fundamental, they are a significant progress, 'as he said, 'It was a great day.'

latest news.eng_title: Russian Deputy Rules Out Another Mobilization
latest news.summary: Russian State Duma Deputy Viktor Vodolatsky believes that there is no need for another mobilization in Russia. According to him, the number of men willing to sign a contract with the Ministry of Defense and join the Special Military Operation (SMO) zone has been increasing lately, allowing the Ministry to meet its manpower needs. As Vodolatsky stated, 'In the next two weeks, everyone will see the maximum increase in liberated territories on the Kherson direction.' He also expressed confidence that there will be no mobilization, saying 'Mobilization will not happen.'

latest news.eng_title: New Rules for Receiving Draft Notices in Russia: What You Need to Know
latest news.summary: Starting from November 1, 2024, new rules for receiving draft notices in Russia will come into effect. The 'Registry of Military Accounting' will be launched, where information about conscripts will be stored. There is less than a month left before the fall draft. Lawyer Marat Samsonov explained the rules: 'The military commissariat can issue draft notices not only personally or through an employer, but also by registered mail and electronically. The document will be placed in the registry, and a notification will appear in the conscript's cabinet on the 'Gosuslugi' website. The document is considered delivered seven days after its placement in the electronic registry, regardless of whether the conscript saw the letter or not.' Draft notices sent by postal mail are considered delivered on the day of delivery, provided there is a notation from the postal service about delivery. Conscripts are required to appear at the military commissariat themselves to verify their data within two weeks of the start of the draft, unless they received a draft notice in the previous draft. This rule does not apply to those who: are under 18 years old; have reached the maximum age of 27 years by December 31, 2023, or 30 years by January 2024; have a deferment or exemption from military service. Deferment from conscription can be obtained by: citizens studying in technical schools, universities on bachelor's, specialist's, and master's programs; employees of IT companies from the state list who have submitted their applications in advance; those with two or more children; those who are the sole breadwinners in their families; and others, as established by law. What can happen if a conscript does not appear at the military commissariat? There is no criminal or administrative liability for not appearing at the military commissariat within two weeks of the start of the draft. However, not appearing at the military commissariat is associated with other risks: receiving a fine for failing to report changes in education or residence, receiving a 'draft dodger' certificate that can hinder further government service, and even being charged with a crime. After the launch of the military accounting registry, it will be impossible to hide from the military commissariat. As Marat Samsonov noted, there are several restrictions introduced to ensure attendance at the military commissariat. Citizens subject to conscription are prohibited from leaving Russia from the date of placement of their draft notice in the registry. Failure to appear without a valid reason within 20 days of receiving a draft notice will result in temporary measures, including restrictions on registering as an individual entrepreneur and self-employed, registering vehicles and driving, registering real estate, and obtaining loans and credits. However, these measures will not be applied until the registry is launched. If a conscript from Petrozavodsk, Karelia, needs legal assistance, they can contact us. We help conscripts: with consultations and assistance in obtaining deferments from the army, recognizing them as unfit for service, and appealing draft decisions. Our lawyers are professionals in the field of conscription and military law. We work on a contract basis and remotely throughout Russia, using our developed schemes and techniques for lawful protection of conscripts' rights.'

latest news.eng_title: Musiienko Evaluates Possibility of Breakthroughs on the Front in Autumn

Organization: Center for Military and Legal Research

latest news.summary: Alexander Musiienko, head of the Center for Military and Legal Research, told RBC-Ukraine that the final battle of autumn 2024 will take place on a specific front. He believes that the active phase of the Russian army's advance may end by October, after which the enemy will need a pause, according to Patriots of Ukraine. Ukraine is expected to hold its defense on the approaches to the Mirmohrad-Pokrovsk direction in the coming weeks, which is the most 'hot' front line. Some Russian 'bloggers' think that the Ukrainian operation in the Kursk region may be a diversionary maneuver before the main blow. The Russians are waiting for a breakthrough of the Ukrainian Defense Forces in the Zaporizhzhia region through Vasylivka to the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Enerhodar and Tokmak. This direction is strategic for Ukraine and logical in the context of the breakthrough. However, the question arises of whether there is anything to work with. Musiienko does not rule out possible breakthroughs in the fall. He emphasized that the situation is constantly changing, so the expert does not rule out Ukrainian operations 'as soon as the moment arises'. 'Point operations can be until the end of the year. A more massive one - in the spring-summer of 2025', - Musiienko says. As for the southern direction, in his words, 'this option is not the most likely, there may be others'.

latest news.eng_title: Central Bank of Russia Postpones Discussion of Publishing Ruble Forecast
latest news.summary: The Central Bank of Russia has postponed the discussion of publishing a forecast for the ruble's exchange rate for autumn 2025. The bank had proposed to expand the list of indicators published in the medium-term macroeconomic forecast, which included the forecast of the currency exchange rate and labor market indicators. However, the Central Bank has decided to postpone the discussion of starting to publish these additional indicators until autumn 2025. The bank cited the recent changes on the internal currency market in June 2024, which included the suspension of trading in dollar/ruble and euro/ruble pairs on the 'Moscow Exchange' due to sanctions. The Central Bank emphasized the need for caution in revealing information about the exchange rate to avoid excessive volatility on the market. Despite this, the bank intends to expand the number of published indicators in the macro forecast in the future, which is necessary to increase the predictability of monetary policy decisions and strengthen market trust.

latest news.eng_title: Perm Region Students Exempt from Military Service in 2024
latest news.summary: In the Perm region, students of higher and secondary vocational educational institutions will not be called to the army in the fall of 2024. This is due to changes in the law on military service, which have come into effect, explained sources in the military commissariats of the Perm region. However, a student must provide a certificate of study to the military commissariat, and a university or college must have state accreditation. 'During the autumn conscription campaign of 2024, students (students) will not receive summonses to the military commissariat, as it was before - they are entitled to a deferment from conscription for the period of study. In this case, the citizen must provide a certificate of study. If a student is expelled from the university or college or expelled, the educational institution must notify the military commissariat within seven days after the expulsion of the student,' explained a source in the regional military commissariat. A source in one of the military commissariats of the city added that this autumn, conscripts will start receiving electronic summonses, which will be duplicated by paper ones for now. 'Despite the mailing of electronic summonses, paper summonses have not disappeared yet. They, as before, will be handed to citizens of conscription age,' noted a source in one of the military commissariats of Perm. The autumn conscription for military service will start on October 1 and will last until December 31, 2024. URA.RU has detailed information on how electronic summonses will be sent, who has the right to defer from military service, and what will happen if a citizen evades military service.

latest news.summary: Former Russian State Duma deputy and opposition politician Gennady Gudkov shared information about the preparation for mobilization in Russia. He mentioned that the plan is to mobilize around 800,000 people or more, but the military commissariats are unlikely to be able to fulfill this task due to the short timeframe. 'The scale of the plan looks amateurish - they plan to mobilize around 800,000 people or more. But the sources say that the military commissariats will not be able to cope with this number. They need to feed, equip, and provide accommodation for these people. Where are they going to put them all? Unrealistic terms and numbers,' Gudkov said. He emphasized that the numbers are indeed very large. The new wave of mobilization is planned in the largest Russian cities, including Moscow, St. Petersburg, Yekaterinburg, and others. Gudkov noted that this information comes from multiple sources connected to the mobilization process, and that Russia is already 90% ready to announce mobilization, with only the political decision remaining.

news knowledge.eng_title: Fall Conscription 2024 in Russia: Key Dates, Electronic Summons, and Exemptions
news knowledge.summary: The fall conscription of 2024 in Russia will take place from October 1 to December 31. The conscription will be conducted using a unified register of military personnel and an open register of summons. Citizens between the ages of 18 and 30 are subject to conscription, unless they have a deferment or exemption from military service. Conscription will last for 12 months, during which time the conscript will undergo military training and learn a specialty. The conscript will have the right to one week of leave and up to 10 days of vacation. If the conscript fails to appear at the military commissariat within 20 days without a valid reason, they will receive a notification of restrictive measures and may face a fine of 10,000 to 30,000 rubles. In addition, the conscript may face restrictions such as the suspension of registration of property rights or the refusal to issue credit or loans. The conscript will undergo a medical examination to determine their fitness for military service, which will be classified into one of four categories: 'A' (fully fit), 'B' (fit with limitations), 'V' (unfit), or 'D' (fully exempt). Those who are classified as 'D' will be fully exempt from military service. Those who are classified as 'V' will only be called up for military service in times of war. Those who are classified as 'B' will be fit for military service with limitations. Those who are classified as 'A' will be fully fit for military service. The conscript may also choose to perform alternative civilian service, which will last for 21 months if they are working in the military sector, or 18 months if they are not. The conscript must submit a request to replace military service with alternative civilian service no later than six months before the start of conscription. The request must include the reasons and circumstances of the decision. The list of organizations where the conscript can perform alternative civilian service is approved by the Ministry of Labor. The conscript may also be exempt from military service if they are a student, a deputy, a member of the MChS, MVD, or FSB, an guardian of a minor, a caregiver for a close relative, a single father, a father of two or more children, a father of a child with a disability under the age of three, or a husband whose wife is pregnant with a second child (over 26 weeks). The conscript may also be exempt from military service if they are a member of an IT company accredited by the Ministry of Digital Development.

news knowledge.eng_title: Russia Develops System to Prevent Potential Draftees from Leaving Country
news knowledge.summary: The Russian government is developing a system to prevent potential draftees and mobilized individuals from leaving the country. According to British intelligence, the system will be fully operational by autumn 2024. The system will allow for the exchange of detailed information between the Ministry of Defense and the FSB border service to prevent individuals from leaving the country. Russia annually conducts two draft calls, mobilizing over 250,000 people for mandatory one-year service. Following the partial mobilization in 2022, hundreds of thousands of Russians left the country, including many young and highly educated individuals, which had a significant impact on the labor market. 'The introduction of this system is likely intended to prevent a repeat of this on a smaller scale during the annual draft cycle and in the event of further mobilization waves,' British intelligence noted. The Russian government is forcing migrants to fight against Ukraine in the Russian army. Of the approximately 30,000 foreigners who recently received Russian passports and did not register for military service, Moscow has already sent a third to the combat zone.

news knowledge.eng_title: Russia to Restrict Travel of Conscripts and Mobilized Individuals
news knowledge.summary: The Russian government plans to restrict the travel of conscripts and mobilized individuals who receive electronic summonses to the military, starting in the fall of 2024. According to several sources, the relevant legislative norms were approved earlier. The electronic register of summonses is expected to start operating in the fall, with automatic restrictions to be implemented. The information was first reported by the Meduza publication, which discovered a tender for the implementation of an 'information exchange' between the Ministry of Defense and the FSB on data about Russians who have received summonses in electronic form. The contract was awarded to the Voskhod research institute, which will transmit the list of individuals subject to military service and with temporary restrictions on leaving Russia to the FSB border service. According to the tender, the contract must be completed by the fall conscription, which usually starts on October 1. The formal deadline for the entire contract is November 29, so the register should be operational during the fall conscription. In December 2023, Vladimir Putin issued an order to hold the fall 2024 conscription using new electronic registers of summonses. Most lawyers believe that all restrictions related to the order will apply to both conscripts and mobilized individuals, and they will be banned from leaving the country immediately after the electronic summons is registered. Rumors about a second massive wave of mobilization in Russia have been circulating periodically throughout 2023. Recently, military experts have been regularly saying that the Russian government is not giving up on a large-scale attack on several still-occupied Ukrainian territories, and the army needs much more manpower. Government representatives have repeatedly stated that there is no need for a second wave of mobilization; similar statements were made before the start of mobilization in the fall of 2022.

news knowledge.eng_title: Kartapолов: Conscripts Called Up During Autumn 2024 Draft Will Not Be Sent to Special Operation
news knowledge.summary: Andrey Kartapолов, the head of the State Duma's Defense Committee, stated that conscripts called up during the autumn 2024 draft will not be sent to a special operation. In response to a journalist's question, Kartapолов assured that the government's position on this matter has not changed. 'As we did not plan to take them, so we will not plan to take them. They will be fine,' Kartapолов said to a correspondent from the Telegram channel Shot. The autumn draft in 2024 will take place in Russia from October 1 to December 31. Men aged 18-30 are subject to conscription, according to the law on increasing the conscription age, which came into effect in January. Recently, the State Duma passed a bill in its first reading, obliging employers to provide information about employees registered for military service to all government information systems designated by the government. The author of the initiative is Kartapолов, who believes that most of the autumn draft will use paper, rather than electronic, summonses, as they have not yet prepared an electronic register.

news knowledge.eng_title: Russia Toughens Draft Law To Bolster War's Lethal Frontlines
news knowledge.summary: Russia is introducing new laws to close loopholes used by those trying to avoid the draft. The changes include serving draft notices online, which will be considered served a week after posting, and collating draft information with other government data. This will allow officials to track citizens' movements and activities more closely. The new system aims to stop young people from leaving the country to avoid being drafted, as many did during the 2022 partial military mobilization. The changes are expected to affect the autumn draft, and may also allow the government to track citizens more closely, making it harder for those trying to evade the draft. The Russian government is preparing for a prolonged conflict in Ukraine, despite recent discussions about resuming peace talks.

news knowledge.eng_title: Kartapолов: Paper Summonses to Remain in Most Russian Regions
news knowledge.summary: According to Andrei Kartapолов, the head of the State Duma's Defense Committee, most regions in Russia will continue to use paper summonses for military conscription during the 2024 autumn conscription period. He stated that the traditional method of notification, using paper summonses, will remain in most subjects. Additionally, the military registration record will also be activated in the fall.

news knowledge.eng_title: Paper Summons to Remain in Most Regions for Autumn Draft
news knowledge.summary: According to Andrey Kartapолов, the head of the State Duma's Defense Committee, most regions in Russia will continue to use paper summons for the 2024 autumn draft. Kartapолов stated that during the autumn draft, notification will be done in the traditional way, using paper summons, in the majority of subjects. Additionally, the military registration database will also be launched in the fall. The database was created by a law signed by Russian President Vladimir Putin in April 2023, which includes personal and passport data, as well as information about education, employment, and health status. The database will not contain information that is state or legally protected secrets.
